Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Metal-Free Carbonyl Additions to Carboxylic Acids Using Diarylphosphine Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the work of Professor Brandon L. Ashfeld at the University of Notre Dame toward the design and development of new phosphorus mediated synthetic strategies for the direct conversion of carboxylic acids to ketones. This research uses an alkyl phosphorus-to-carbon ligand transfer that enables the formation of new carbon-carbon bonds with high levels of chemoselectivity and effectively allows for an operationally simple and efficient approach toward synthetic targets through unconventional bond constructs. This study expands the role of carboxylic acids and phosphorus reagents in synthesis and introduces new and exciting strategies for complex molecule synthesis.

The long term impact of this research program is the development of synthetic strategies that enable the construction of new and complex compounds useful for scientific research pharmaceutical industry. The educational component of this CAREER award describes a series of outreach initiatives to inspire secondary students to pursue careers in the physical sciences, the development of an undergraduate course in energy sustainability, and the design of an interactive, web-based workbook to serve as a valuable resource for students and educators of chemistry. The combined research and education components constitute the foundation of this training program, and address the fundamental issues of safety, environmental friendliness, energy conservation, and cost of chemical research. Recruitment and training of undergraduate students, women, and under-represented minorities to chemistry, and the physical sciences, is a key aspect of this multi-faceted program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research outcomes that were generated from the National Science Foundation CAREER award associated with the federal award ID# 1056242 related directly to the development of new synthetic methods in organic chemistry to more efficiently and cost effectively construct complex molecular scaffolds that are relevant to current and future needs in the pharmaceutical industry and materials science. The avoidance of costly and esoteric reagents required to affect the desired transformations was of paramount importance and emphasized over the entire funding period of this award. This work resulted in the discovery, design, and development of new methods for the assembly of ring structures that are important scaffolds for small molecules that are known to exhibit promising chemotherapeutic potential and as materials for more energy efficient industrial applications. These efforts demonstrated how low cost and readily available reagents could be used to construct small molecules in a highly selective fashion with exceptional yields, and opened the door to promising new discoveries in chemical synthesis. These findings were disseminated in over 25 publications that were published in reputable, peer reviewed journals recognized internationally as leaders in their respective areas. Additionally, numerous conference presentations and departmental seminars at industrial and academic institutions were made possible by this work and used to the effectively communicate the results to scientific and broader audiences. The personnel outcomes associated with this award include eight doctoral theses and  enabled 12 undergraduates at the University of Notre Dame to gain valuable research experience that will serve them throughout their future research and medical careers. The broad educational outcomes of this project includes community outreach to area high schools designed to encourage collegiate pursuits, the development of a new course to be added to the Notre Dame curriculum for a minor in sustainability that will focus on chemical catalysis, and establishment of an interactive web-based program designed as a working resource for students and educators studying chemical sustainability. Significant effort was expended in developing a platform for students in grades K-12 to become involved in the chemical disciplines thereby promoting these future pursuits for the next generation of scientists and engineers.
